Consider these data

$$
X_1,\,X_2,\,...,\,X_n\overset{\text{iid}}{\sim}\text{N}(\theta,\,1)
$$

and the usual estimator $\hat{\theta}_n=\sum\limits_{i=1}^nX_i/n$.

a. Derive an exact $100\times (1-\alpha)\%$ classical confidence interval for the unknown mean $\theta$. That is, find a random interval $(L_n,\,U_n)$ satisfying:

$$
P\left(L_n<\theta<U_n\right)=1-\alpha.
$$

b. Derive an exact $100\times (1-\alpha)\%$ classical *prediction* interval for a new observation $X_{n+1}$. That is, find a random interval $(L_n',\,U_n')$ satisfying

$$
P\left(L_n'<X_{n+1}<U_n'\right)=1-\alpha.
$$

c. Comment on the difference between the two intervals.
